bill.title: Keeping Our Commitment to Ending Veteran Homelessness Act of 2015

item.title: Keeping Our Commitment to Ending Veteran Homelessness Act of 2015
A bill to amend title 38, United States Code, to extend authorities relating to homeless veterans, and for other purposes.
Keeping Our Commitment to Ending Veteran Homelessness Act of 2015

item.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

item.text:
Keeping Our Commitment to Ending Veteran Homelessness Act of 2015

This bill extends through FY2016 authority for the following Department of Veterans Affairs programs:

  • homeless veterans reintegration programs;
  • the homeless women veterans and homeless veterans with children reintegration program;
  • referral and counseling services for certain veterans at risk of homelessness;
  • treatment and rehabilitation services for seriously mentally ill and homeless veterans, including a program to provide homeless veterans with benefits and services at certain locations;
  • housing assistance for homeless veterans;
  • financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing; and
  • the grant program for homeless veterans with special needs.

Extends through December 31, 2016, authority for the Advisory Committee on Homeless Veterans.
item.name: Introduced in Senate

item.latestTitle: Department of Veterans Affairs Expiring Authorities Act of 2015
Keeping Our Commitment to Ending Veteran Homelessness Act of 2016

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
